title-group.article-title: Chlorhexidine Inhibits the Activity of Dental Cysteine Cathepsins

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Restorative Dentistry, Piracicaba Dental School, State University of Campinas, Piracicaba, Brazil
2Department of Biophysics, Federal University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil
3Department of Biochemistry, Federal University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil
4Department of Biomedicine, University of Trieste, and IGM-CNR and Unit of Bologna c/o IOR, Bologna, Italy
5Department of Oral Biology, College of Dental Medicine, Georgia Health Sciences University, Augusta, GA, USA
6Institute of Dentistry, University of Oulu and Oulu University Hospital, Oulu, Finland
7Centro Interdisciplinar de Investigação Bioquímica, University of Mogi das Cruzes, Mogi das Cruzes, Brazil
8Biomaterials Research Group, Bandeirante University of São Paulo, Rua Maria Cândida, 1813, 6 andar, São Paulo, 02071-013, Brazil

permissions.copyright-holder: International & American Associations for Dental Research

abstract.p: The co-expression of MMPs and cysteine cathepsins in the human dentin-pulp complex indicates that both classes of enzymes can contribute to the endogenous proteolytic activity of dentin. Chlorhexidine (CHX) is an efficient inhibitor of MMP activity. This study investigated whether CHX could also inhibit cysteine cathepsins present in dentin. The inhibitory profile of CHX on the activity of dentin-extracted and recombinant cysteine cathepsins (B, K, and L) was monitored in fluorogenic substrates. The rate of substrate hydrolysis was spectrofluorimetrically measured, and inhibitory constants were calculated. Molecular docking was performed to predict the binding affinity between CHX and cysteine cathepsins. The results showed that CHX inhibited the proteolytic activity of dentin-extracted cysteine cathepsins in a dose-dependent manner. The proteolytic activity of human recombinant cathepsins was also inhibited by CHX. Molecular docking analysis suggested that CHX strongly interacts with the subsites S2 to S2′ of cysteine cathepsins B, K, and L in a very similar manner. Taken together, these results clearly showed that CHX is a potent inhibitor of the cysteine cathepsins-proteolytic enzymes present in the dentin-pulp complex.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Identification of matrix metalloproteases (MMPs) (Mazzoni et al., 2007; Sulkala et al., 2007) and determination of their activity in dentin matrix (Pashley et al., 2004) support the notion that these proteases play a central role in the proteolytic degradation of poorly resin-infiltrated dentin matrices in adhesive restorations (Pashley et al., 2011).

In addition to MMPs, lysosomal papain-like cysteine proteases from the cathepsin family have been shown to participate in various physiological and pathological conditions which result in the degradation of extracellular matrix components (Turk et al., 1997; Dickinson, 2002; Li et al., 2004). Recently, the gene expression for different cysteine cathepsins was demonstrated in human pulp and odontoblasts, with the major presence of cathepsin B (Tersariol et al., 2010). Moreover, cysteine cathepsin activities in dentin and their correlation with MMPs activities were also detected (Tersariol et al., 2010). These findings strongly suggest that MMPs and cysteine cathepsins may be responsible for the endogenous proteolytic activity of dentin, contributing to collagen degradation, not only within hybrid layers (Hebling et al., 2005; Carrilho et al., 2007) but also in caries lesions (Tjäderhane et al., 1998; Nascimento et al., 2011).

The success of chlorhexidine (CHX) in increasing the durability of resin-dentin bonds has been mainly credited to its ability to strongly inhibit the proteolytic activity of MMP-2, -8, and -9 (Gendron et al., 1999), 3 of the MMPs identified in human dentin (Martin-de Las Heras et al., 2000; Mazzoni et al., 2007; Sulkala et al., 2007). The use of specific MMP inhibitors, like Galardin, can reduce the host-derived proteolytic activity of dentin (Breschi et al., 2010). However, since MMPs are not the only proteases present in dentin, a broad-spectrum inhibitor could be essential to inhibiting other dentinal proteolytic enzymes. Since CHX has other clinically advantageous features—such as antimicrobial function (Lessa et al., 2010a), high substantivity to dentin matrix (Carrilho et al., 2010; Kim et al., 2010), and minor transdentinal cytotoxicity (Lessa et al., 2010b)—it is important to determine whether CHX possesses non-specific inhibitory activity against dentinal cysteine cathepsins.

The objective of this study was to investigate the potential interaction between CHX and the cysteine cathepsins B, L, and K. The tested hypothesis was that chlorhexidine interacts with and inhibits cysteine cathepsins.

sec.title: Materials & Methods
sec.p: Three experiments were performed: (1) monitoring of proteolytic activity of dentin extracts in the absence and presence of an aqueous solution of chlorhexidine digluconate (CHX), using a cysteine cathepsins-fluorogenic substrate, Z-FR-MCA (Carbobenzoxy- Phe-Arg-4-methylcoumarin-7-amide) and its specific inhibitor E-64; (2) monitoring the activity of recombinant human cathepsins B, L, and K in the presence/absence of CHX; and (3) estimation of the affinity between CHX and cathepsins by molecular docking.
Reagents were purchased from Sigma Chemical (St. Louis, MO, USA) unless otherwise specified.

sec.title: Monitoring of the Proteolytic Activity in Dentin Extracts
sec.p: Fifteen freshly extracted human molars obtained from young individuals (23-31 yrs) were used in this protocol, which was approved by the IRB Committee of Piracicaba School of Dentistry/UNICAMP. After complete removal of enamel and cementum, fragments of mid-coronal dentin from all teeth were obtained, pooled, dried with acetone for 5 min, and frozen at −80ºC for 24 hrs. Those fragments were further reduced in a ball-mill (MM401, Retsch, Newtown, PA, USA) at 30 Hz for 7 min. The resultant powder was sieved (#400 mesh), and a 1.2-g aliquot of dentin was used for enzyme extraction, according to a protocol described previously (Martin-de Las Heras et al., 2000). Briefly, dentin powder was treated with 4 M guanidine-HCl (G1-extract), then demineralized with 0.5 M ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA-extracts), and again treated with 4 M guanidine-HCl (G2-extract). The amount of protein in the G2-extract was determined by the Bio-Rad dye-binding assay (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc., Hercules, CA, USA), which is based on Bradford’s method (Bradford, 1976).

Cysteine cathepsin activities in dentin G2-extracts were monitored with the fluorogenic substrate Z-FR-MCA in a Genius Tecanfluorometer (Mannedorf, Switzerland). Z-FR-MCA is a suitable substrate for cysteine cathepsins, due to its amino acid sequence, which covers S3, S2, S1, and S1′, the main substrate-binding sites in the papain-like cysteine proteases (Barrett, 1980; Nägler et al., 1997). Prior to the assay, 10-µL aliquots of dentin extracts were activated in 50 mM 2-(N-morpholino ethane) sulfonic acid buffer (pH 5.5) containing 1 mM dithiothreitol for 5 min at 37ºC. Excitation and emission wavelengths were set at 380 and 460 nm, respectively. The kinetics of 5 µM Z-FR-MCA hydrolysis was performed in the same activating buffer, in the absence or presence of CHX (final concentrations between 0 and 10 mM). Substrate hydrolysis was determined by measurement of the rate increase of fluorescence at 460 nm. The experiments were performed in quadruplicate. The selective substrate hydrolysis was checked with 5 µM E-64, a specific inhibitor of cysteine protease (Dickinson, 2002). The enzyme activity was verified for linear variations in reaction time with an increasing volume of samples. The specific activities were calculated with reference to total protein.

sec.title: Monitoring of Activity of Recombinant Cathepsins B, L, and K
sec.p: Recombinant cathepsins B, L (Calbiochem, San Diego, CA, USA), and K (expressed and purified in our lab) were used. The activity of these enzymes was also monitored with the Z-FR-MCA substrate in a Hitachi fluorometer (Scientific Instruments, Inc., Hialeah, FL, USA) with and without CHX at pH 5, as described above. Cathepsin B is the only member of the papain superfamily to exhibit both endo- and exopeptidase (carboxydipeptidylpeptidase) activity. At lower pH, as found in lysosomes (4.5-5.5), cathepsin B acts primarily as an exopeptidase (Musil et al., 1991), while at higher pH (6.7-7.4), it exhibits an endopeptidase activity (Nägler et al., 1997). Thus, for cathepsin B, the monitoring of substrate hydrolysis was also performed at pH 6.7.

The rate of substrate hydrolysis was continuously monitored by measurement of the rate of fluorescence increase at 460 nm as a function of time. The enzyme concentration for initial rate determinations was chosen so that < 5% of the substrate was hydrolyzed. The data were analyzed and equations were fitted in GraFit (version 5.0; Erithacus Software Ltd., Horley, UK). The equation used to calculate the KI values for CHX inhibition was KI = KIapp/ (1 + [S]/KM), where [S] = molar concentration of the substrate, KM = Michaelis constant, and KIapp = apparent inhibition constant. KIapp was calculated according to the equation (V0/Vi) = 1 + [I]/KIapp, where V0 = velocity of hydrolysis without the inhibitor, Vi = velocity of hydrolysis in the presence of the inhibitor, and [I] = molar concentration of CHX. A plot of (V0/Vi) −1 vs. [I] yields a slope of 1/KIapp (Machado et al., 2007).

Additionally, we measured binding of CHX by determining the change in intrinsic fluorescence of tryptophan residues in human recombinant cathepsin B. Intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence was monitored by measurement of the fluorescence emission (λem) of 1 µM cathepsin B concentration at 300-450 nm (5-nm slit) after excitation at λex = 285 nm (5-nm slit) with a Hitachi spectrofluorometer. The interaction of CHX with recombinant cathepsin B was determined by measurement of the change in intrinsic fluorescence observed in the presence of 100 µM CHX in 50 mm MES, pH 5.5, 37°C. Signal from buffer alone was subtracted from the readings, to eliminate the background (Gesteira et al., 2011).

sec.title: Molecular Docking Analysis of CHX and Cysteine Cathepsin Interactions
sec.p: A mathematical modeling approach (i.e., molecular docking) was used to predict the binding affinity between CHX and cathepsins. Docking simulations were carried out with the Autodock 4.2 package (The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA, USA). CHX parameters were generated by a MMFF94s force field (Halgren, 1999) as ionized forms. For consistency of partial charges with receptors, single-point calculations were performed with the General Atomic and Molecular Electronic Structure System (GAMESS) (Gordon and Schmidt, 2005) to obtain the electrostatic potential with HF/6-31G* level of theory, with equivalent atoms given equal partial charges. CHX input was prepared in an Autotors module in Autodock 4.2. The structures of cathepsins K, B, and L were retrieved from the Protein Data Bank (Thompson et al., 1997; Berman et al., 2000; Greenspan et al., 2001; Chowdhury et al., 2002) and prepared as previously described (Gesteira et al., 2011). The Autogrid settings were averaged around the catalytic triad, with grid spacing of 0.327 Å for grid preparation. The Lamarckian Genetic Algorithm (LGA) was used to explore the space of the binding site, centered on the CHX interaction site on each cathepsin molecule. Step sizes of 2 Å for translation and 15 Å for rotation were chosen, and the maximum number of energy evaluations was set at 300,000. For each run, a maximum number of 270,000 LGA operations was generated on populations of 200 individuals. Operator weights for crossover, mutation, and elitism were set at 0.80, 0.02, and 1, respectively. The orientations of ligand molecules at the binding sites were selected from the docked conformations as representative of the lower-energy clusters generated by Autodock 4.2.

sec.title: Effect of CHX on the Proteolytic Activity of Dentinal Extracted Cysteine Cathepsins
sec.p: Proteolytic activity of cysteine cathepsins in dentin extracts was detected and severely inhibited by the specific inhibitor for this class of enzymes E-64 (Fig. 1), demonstrating the presence of cysteine cathepsins in demineralized dentin matrix. CHX inhibited the activity of dentinal proteases in a concentration-dependent manner (IC50 = 0.8 mM).

caption.p: Inhibition of endopeptidase activities of cysteine cathepsins in dentin extracts. The activity of cysteine cathepsins in G-2 extracts, expressed in arbitrary units of fluorescence (AUF), was monitored with the fluorogenic substrates Z-FR-MCA as described in MATERIALS & METHODS. The substrate hydrolysis was performed in the absence (dentin extracts column) or in the presence of different CHX digluconate concentrations (0.02-10 mM CHX columns). The enzymatic activity of dentin extracts was also determined in the presence of 5 µM E-64 concentration (E-64 column) or in the presence of 5 µM E-64 + 10 mM CHX digluconate concentration (E-64 + CHX column).

sec.title: Effect of CHX on Recombinant Cathepsins B, K, and L
sec.p: As was observed in dentin extracts, the activity of recombinant cathepsins was also inhibited with increasing concentrations of CHX (Fig. 2). At pH 5.5, cathepsin B was inhibited by CHX, with a Ki of 220 ± 20 µM (IC50 = 0.8 mM), and at pH 6.7, with a Ki of 16 ± 2 µM (Fig. 2A). The interaction between CHX and cathepsin B, monitored by measurement of the intrinsic fluorescence of tryptophan residues, showed that CHX suppressed 32% of the intrinsic fluorescence of recombinant human cathepsin B (Fig. 2B). CHX strongly inhibited cathepsin K, with a Ki of 14 ± 2 µM, and cathepsin L, with a Ki of 1.2 ± 0.1 µM (Figs. 2C, 2D).

caption.p: Effect of CHX on Z-FR-MCA hydrolysis by human recombinant cathepsins B, K, and L upon the intrinsic fluorescence of cathepsins B. (A) The influence of CHX digluconate concentration upon cathepsin B endopeptidase activity was determined spectrofluorimetrically by measurement of the Z-FR-MCA hydrolysis at pH 5.5 (▲) or at pH 6.7 (●), as described in MATERIALS & METHODS. (B) CHX-induced changes in the intrinsic fluorescence of recombinant cathepsin B. The emission spectra were obtained for 1.0 μM recombinant cathepsin B alone (●) or in the presence of 100 μM chlorhexidine (▲). The influence of chlorhexidine concentration upon cathepsin K (C) and cathepsin L (D) endopeptidase activities was also determined spectrofluorimetrically by measurement of the Z-FR-MCA hydrolysis, in 50 mM MES, pH 5.7, containing 1 mM DTT at 37ºC.

sec.title: Molecular Docking Analysis of CHX Interaction with Cysteine Cathepsins
sec.p: Molecular docking of CHX was modeled with the crystal structure of cathepsins B, K, and L, assuming that the minimum energy represents the best model for a CHX binding site. Fig. 3 shows the optimal docking site for CHX in three-dimensional cysteine cathepsin structures, indicating that the amino acid residues from subsites S2 to S2′ of the cysteine cathepsins B, K, and L interact with CHX molecules (Table). Results indicate that the interaction between CHX and cathepsins B, K, and L occurs similarly. (For details of the molecular docking analysis, see the Appendix.)

caption.p: Representation of the complex of CHX with cysteine cathepsins B, K, and L. The secondary structure elements of each enzyme are represented by cyan blue schematics (arrows for extended strands and cylinders for helices), while the carbon atoms of CHX are indicated by light green sticks. The active site residues of the cysteine cathepsins B, K, and L are labeled following the numbering of papain. (A) Docking of CHX with cathepsin B: View of the minimum energy conformation showing CHX completely engulfed in the cathepsin B active site cavity from S2 to S2′: Cys29 and His199 are the active site residues (light yellow). The amino acid residues Tyr75, Pro76, and Glu245 (red) are at the subsite S2; Gly74 (red) and Cys29 (light yellow) residues are at the subsite S1, and the His199 (light yellow) residue is at the subsite S1′ of cathepsin B. (B) Docking of CHX with cathepsin K: View of the minimum energy conformation showing CHX completely engulfed onto the cathepsin K active site cavity from S2 to S2′: Cys25, His159, and Asn175 are the active site residues (light yellow). The amino acid residues Gln19 (red) and Cys25 (light yellow) are at the subsite S1; Gly20, Gly23 (red) are at the subsite S2′ of the cathepsin K. (C) Docking of CHX with cathepsin L: View of the minimum energy conformation showing CHX engulfed onto the cathepsin L active site cavity from S2 to S2′: Cys25 and His159 are the active site residues (light yellow). The amino acid residues Ala133 and Leu157 (red) are at the subsite S2; Gln19 (red) and Cys25 (light yellow) are at the subsite S1; Gly23 (red) is at the subsite S2′ of the cathepsin L.
Binding distances between chx digluconate and subsites of the catalytic domain of cysteine cathepsins B, K, and L

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Hydrolysis of the fluorogenic substrate Z-FR-MCA incubated with dentin extracts confirmed the assumption that the host-derived proteolytic activity of dentin is partially due to the expression of cysteine cathepsins (Tersariol et al., 2010; Nascimento et al., 2011) in addition to that due to MMPs. In conjunction, the 3 experiments indicated that CHX has a strong interaction with cathepsins, inhibiting the activity of these enzymes dose-dependently. These results, therefore, support the acceptance of the proposed hypothesis.

Recent descriptions of the expression of cysteine cathepsins in cultured odontoblasts and pulp tissues (Tersariol et al., 2010) and their reported activity in sound and carious dentin (Tersariol et al., 2010; Nascimento et al., 2011) embody the notion that these enzymes can participate in metabolic processes involving the degradation of dentin matrix components. While cathepsins B and L were reported to cleave non-helical telopeptide extensions of collagens, cathepsin K, in the presence of chondroitin 4-sulfate, may cleave the triple-helical structure of collagens, showing true collagenolytic activity (Li et al., 2004).

The synthetic inhibitor E-64 irreversibly inhibits several cysteine proteases (Dickinson, 2002). The present results showed, for the first time, that CHX also promoted a significant inhibition of cathepsin activity, comparable with that observed with E-64.

CHX is characterized as a strong base with cationic properties and with a potential ability to bind to the negatively charged surface/site of target substrates (Nerurkar et al., 1995). Molecular docking modeling confirmed that electrostatic binding between CHX and cathepsins is possible and easily achievable. For instance, the guanidyl group of CHX established an electrostatic interaction of 2.60 Å with the carboxylate group of Glu122 residue at subsite S1 of cathepsin B, mimicking the guanidyl group of a peptidic substrate with arginine residue at P1. Also, the carboxylate group of Glu245 at the S2 subsite of cathepsin B is well-placed at 2.88 Å from the guanidyl group of chlorhexidine, mimicking the guanidyl group of a peptidic substrate with arginine residue at P2.

Interactions between CHX and cathepsins varied based on enzyme structure, but they were all effective in reducing the rate of Z-FR-MCA substrate hydrolysis. Effectiveness on protease inhibition was dependent on three-dimensional interactions between CHX with the amino acid residues from the active sites of these enzymes. The molecular docking analysis of CHX showed that the subsites S2 to S2′ of cathepsins B, K, and L are occupied by the CHX molecule.

The inhibition of cathepsin B with CHX was pH-dependent. As previously demonstrated, at acidic pH, Asp22 and His110 residues form a salt bridge in the mature cathepsin B (Musil et al., 1991) that stabilizes the occluding loop of the enzyme in its closed conformation (Nägler et al., 1997), thereby hiding its active site cleft. At higher pH (neutral), there is deprotonation of His110 and destruction of the Asp22-His110 salt bridge, which displaces the occluding loop (Quraishi et al., 1999) and exposes the active site cleft of the enzyme. These events could explain why the inhibition of cathepsin B by CHX was more effective at pH 6.7.

The interaction of CHX with Trp221 at subsite S1′ and with Trp30 at subsite S1 of the cathepsin B active site (Musil et al., 1991) suppresses the intrinsic fluorescence of cathepsin B. It is important to note that cathepsin B has 7 tryptophan residues in its composition, and that CHX produced a decrease of 30% in the intrinsic fluorescence of tryptophan residues present in it. This strongly suggests that CHX can indeed interact with the active site of cathepsin B.

Molecular docking analysis also suggested that the participation of the hydrogen atom HAK of CHX may control the mechanism of cathepsin B inhibition. Interestingly, the hydrogen atom HAK is 2.32 Å equidistant from the catalytic Cys29 thiolate-imidazole His199 ion pairing, suggesting that HAK is an important group of the CHX directly related to the mechanism of cathepsin B inhibition.

Thus, the well-demonstrated effect of CHX in preserving the integrity of dentin collagen may be due not only to the inhibition of MMPs, but also to the inhibition of dentinal cysteine cathepsins. Although the inhibition of cathepsins by CHX has been observed in this work, further investigations into the involvement and importance of this class of enzymes in caries pathogenesis and hybrid layer degradation may allow for the development of more effective prevention modes for these oral disorders.

A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
